documents.document: Great new work by @lelandtlr and co on GxE interactions in skeletal muscle https://t.co/apasCqk2Dh

Best Bioinformatics paper title of the year? "seXY: a tool for sex inference from genotype arrays" https://t.co/opLOlaouNy
The most important thing you can do for science today: weigh in on citing preprints in @NIH grant applications: https://t.co/p4KSHYECGU.
Zomg, the BBC iPlayer volume control goes to 11
@giessel @abarysh This is a really great insight! I will definitely use this.
AK: metagraph + bz2 compression of all NCBI viral sequences -> 7% of raw sequence size #BioData16
AK taking about applying succinct de Bruijn Graphs (https://t.co/Ja4WhMMNiP) to metagenomics #BioData16
Great hacking with my #BioData16 hackathon team @morgantaschuk, Upendra, @DCGenomics, and Andrew! WIP here: https://t.co/JmywYSiRu5
Mendelian diseases are rare, but reduced expression of Mendelian disease genes is not. NC #BioData16
@jeremy_m_simon Monocle orders single cells in a single experiment, where as @BeEngelhardt 's methods require data from multiple time points
@jeremy_m_simon If I understand Monocle correctly, it's meant for a different class of data than what @BeEngelhardt presented. 1/2
I think this is the best equation slide I've ever seen #BioData16
Correlation vs causation: is methylation an indicator of binding, or does it cause/discourage binding? MH looking into it #BioData16
MH CTCF dislikes methylated sequences, ZFP57 loves em #BioData16
MEME suite now works with arbitrary genetic alphabets #BioData16
MH Just add more rows to the PWM for compatibility with existing motif analysis strategies #BioData16
.@michaelhoffman expands the epigenetic alphabet used to predict methyl-sensitive TF binding #BioData16
OT Clarification: training on quantitative data; predicting fold-change #BioData16
Beautiful master lecture from @OlgaTroyanskaya at #BioData16 : very motivating to see what's possible with DNNs
@michaelhoffman Never is a long time. I think that translates into '5 years' in ML time.
@iddux True, but we need more GPU power to make them really Huuuuugeee
OT Hyperparameter choice is human-intensive; little theory to direct optimal choice - still mostly empirical #BioData16
OT It's not so much how much data you have as the dimensionality vs sample size that determines whether DNNs will work #BioData16
@GholsonLyon creative disruption of the scientific method
OT should live-code a neural network to learn the relationship between real time and the CSHL clock #BioData16
OT Many posible DNN architectures (here's a handy list: https://t.co/g6xavI9o8j) #BioData16
OT "In machine learning, you never get a free pass" #BioData16
OT Deep Learning: composable models trainable by gradient #BioData16
@giessel @CSHL Looking forward to the Pan-Gourd Genome Project
@notthatdrjones @biorxivpreprint Yes, this has been successful at NHGRI. It's great for grads/postdocs to get experience reviewing papers.
Very impressed with @anshul lab dedication to open science - everything on GitHub, biorxiv #BioData16
AS MoDiSco: identify high-important features, cluster -> more accurate motifs, incl flanking regions that suggest co-binding #BioData16
AS Challenges: Getting the reference activation correct - use different references depending on genomic context #BioData16 2/2
AS Backprop (gradient descent) has limitations: saturation, thresholding; solutions: use difference from reference activation #BioData16 1/2
AS In Silico Mutagenesis not computationally feasible for long sequences #BioData16
AS Can we build a neural network to distinguish @anshul from @OlgaTroyanskaya? I hope so #BioData16
Time to hear about DeepLIFT! #BioData16
GD When same SNP is most significant across conditions, effect size is reproducible; with different SNPs, all bets are off #BioData16
@David_McGaughey don't think so, but I'll ask
GD sim shows true eQTL effect (causal SNP) hidden by more signif (false) assns; interested to see how this compares with coloc #BioData16
YH all features contribute a small amount to the final prediction (0.02 - 0.05) #BioData16
YH working on applying DeepINSIGHT to noncoding variation #BioData16
YH DeepINSIGHT, Eigen close to upper bound of prediction accuracy for functional impact of BRAC1 mutations #BioData16
YH DeepINSIGHT: neural network learns selection coef from genomic features, feed through mixture model to predict function effect #BioData16
YFH lims. of fitCons: can't est selection coefficient, linear (can't capture higher-order interactions); alternative: DeepINSIGHT #BioData16
Clarification: "more than 5"
What's the lower bound on timepoints for transcriptional response analysis? .@BeEngelhardt : depends, but 12 is pushing the limit #BioData16
.@BeEngelhardt boldly showing a three-equation slide at 9:07am #needmorecoffee #BioData16
.@BeEngelhardt need new methods adapted to specific properties of transcriptional response data #BioData16
Transcriptional response data != traditional time-series. Resp not stationary, sparse sampling of obs, resp time diff by gene BEE #BioData16
@morgantaschuk It's pretty cool! Although it takes about 200G memory to build the index. Which I guess isn't much anymore?
@lpachter At BoG 15, was a rule that first question had to be from trainee; fixed gender disparity (after norm. for audience composition)
@anshul lab DragoNN is a great resource -- nice tutorials for getting up and running with genomic #deeplearning #BioData16
RI: Currently applying GC bias correction to ChIP-seq because "it's there" #BioData16
Rafa shows a model to predict coverage based on CG content correct for bias (Alpine) - now incorporated into Salmon #BioData16
@michaelhoffman @realDonaldTrump Somehow I don't think he'd cluster with the rest of the human samples
Rafa demonstrates the enduring beauty of base R plots #BioData16
Rafa on the typical bioinfo workflow: raw data -> pre-processing -> analysis -> knowledge! #BioData16
@rarbrew @UnionBrewing complete 180 after the VIP session was over… Bathroom lines a mile long, water jugs empty; not going back next year
Best Baltimore Craft Beer Fest yet! Fantastic harvest beers from @rarbrew @UnionBrewing and many more
Looking forward to @cshlmeetings #BIODATA16 next week. Can’t wait to hackathon with @DCGenomics and others!
@GeneticsGSA #G3 is piloting a new article format, the "genome report," and we're the guinea pigs :) https://t.co/AG0PQ78PCY @_apm0
@JennyBryan @ShriramKMurthi jebus do I love this piece so much…kudos to an academic standing up for the importance of CS education!

New read trimming software Atropos -- preprint: https://t.co/dQdn9AtiiF; GitHub: https://t.co/oab27bjsy7; "pip install atropos" on py3.3+

@HandsomeBeerCo I just bought some at Dominion in Falls Church
Every scientist has a different reason for doing what they do; to me, the personal stories are the most inspiring https://t.co/HrJyLbXALu
Must faster than SeqPurge; faster than Skewer with 16 threads...what other trimmers should I benchmark against?
Atropos is a fork of Cutadapt with multi-threading support and other usability improvements: https://t.co/oab27bjsy7 ; preprint coming soon

Today I joined the ranks of @swcarpentry instructors! Looking forward to teaching my first workshop @NIH in October

@dccc_phd I don't see me ("The Impostor")

Favorite paper title in a long time: “Dumpster diving in RNA-sequencing to find the source of every last read” https://t.co/X49o5mkB3j
@anavinuela bigger names and/or sexier topics/titles…But certainly not necessarily“better”
@anavinuela share the work, input from multiple ppl, + benefit of learning about cutting edge research (i.e. 6 mo or more ahead of pub) 2/2
@anavinuela probably true, and reviews are biased towards "more interesting" papers. But I think preprint journal clubs can help: 1/2
The power of preprints: authors substantially improving their paper thanks to comments from our journal club: https://t.co/fvfPReQlRJ
I love finding frustrated debugging messages accidentally left in production (or at least published) code. https://t.co/AoC6xxl4D8
Conservatives hate political correctness until you mock one of their icons https://t.co/TMzLccsVEn
JN: find several genes that display wooing behavior, incl Apobec1, Adar1, Pum1, Ddx1; wicked ascertainment bias - how many more? #NIHTI16
JN: Dnd1 KO - no homozygotes, but no decrease in litter size; interpretation is preferential fertilization, i.e. "gametes woo" #NIHTI16
Looking forward to part 3 of Joe Nadeau's talk at #NIHTI16: "Do gametes woo?"
3. If 20% of gametes have epigenome perturbed, only 20% of offspring should inherit (*unless* affected gametes more/less fit) #NIHTI16 3/3
@HopeJahren @dccc_phd @POTUS @NSF here here! And let's not forget @NIH as well.
2. Consider all confounding factors: DNA sequence variability, cell subtype proportion, mosicism, many more 2/3 #NIHTI16
John Greally on epigenomics experiments: 1. Know your hypothesis: env perturbs cell type? env changes lineage commitement? #NIHTI16 1/3
@EpgntxEinstein @meandertail @NIH let's go with #NIHTI16
@ljdursi @gvwilson @pathogenomenick an epic tale of debugging. Kudos!

How I feel when the LaTeX table looks passable after two hours of trying https://t.co/Xo3qXELbL1
Also, mapping rate >99%, better than next-fastest Bison (11h with 5 x 6 = 30 cores).
Impressed w bwa-meth https://t.co/1epla8TvRg. 10h to map 350M PE bisulfite reads w 16 threads. Bowtie2 and LAST still running after >1 day.
This month our preprint journal club reviews https://t.co/ulb7TSB1G3 from @BeEngelhardt & co. If you're @NIH, join us in 50-5328 at noon!
